course_title: Tops: French Literature: Literature on the Alert
class_notes:
LITERATURE ON THE ALERT
Nouvet T 1:00-4:00pm
Content: To be on the alert implies not only foreboding, but also vigilance, an awakening of sorts , a warning even. Literature can be on the alert in all of those senses. Both the love poetry of the troubadours as well as surrealist "mad love" alerts us to the presence of "something" that is not an object, but something else much more terrifying. Elevated through sublimation or degraded into comical obscenity, it turns poetry and narrative into an infinite address. This "something" can also make its presence felt as an affliction at the core of the social space. This alarm resonates, in various ways and different contexts (World Wars I and II), in Apollinaire's poetry, Bataille's Blue of Noon and Gracq's The Opposing Shore. As it attends to these afflictions, literature can become a strange wake-up call that breaks through everyday slumber to transmit what Gracq called "something like a far-away alarm."  
The course will be taught in English. Texts will be read in their English translations.
